Kiss Of The Dragon's Realism meets Style action makes up for its basic story.

Liu Siu-jian (Jet Li), a Chinese intelligence agent, is sent to Paris to help apprehend Chinese mob boss Mr. Big (Ric Young), who is involved in heroin smuggling. He meets Inspector Jean-Pierre Richard (Tchky Karyo), a corrupt and violent French police detective, at a hotel. Richard tricks Liu into believing he is simply providing reconnaissance of a meet involving Mr. Big. The plans are changed when Mr. Big is introduced to two prostitutes, one being Jessica Kamen (Bridget Fonda), an American woman, who takes him to his room to service him. While Liu and the rest are watching through the surveillance camera, Mr. Big kicks everyone out except for two women. After pretending to seduce him, one of the women then stabs Mr. Big. Overseeing the events from a surveillance room, Liu rushes to stop the killing, but Richard enters shortly later to shoot Mr. Big and the woman with Liu's police-issued handgun, framing Liu for the murders. Realizing he has been set up, Liu manages to escape from the hotel with a surveillance tape showing Richard shooting Mr. Big. Chinese liaisons are sent to France after the events to investigate the matter, as Richard makes Liu the primary suspect. However, the liaisons do not believe the story Richard provides. Liu manages to contact one of the liaisons, and passes on to him the tape that reveals the truth. Due to French police surveillance, the meet between the liaison and Liu is spotted, and the liaison is assassinated. Liu is then forced to flee from a horde of cops and even GIGN commandos. After Liu escapes, he is forced to maintain a low profile...

The movie met with mixed reaction from critics, who thought violence overwhelmed it at the expense of the story and even a true portrayal of martial arts. The fans generally rated it as better than Jet Li's other American films (Romeo Must Die, The One and Cradle 2 the Grave). Due to its violence, "Kiss of the Dragon" was banned in China. Li spoke out about this censorship.

"Kiss of The Dragon" (Le Baiser mortel du dragon) is a Jet Li action vehicle to show of his martial arts skills with a pretty vague storyline, over the top violence and not much else. The film is based on a story by Li, and is one of Fonda's final on-screen appearances before her retirement from acting. Tchky Karyo does what he does best, a mad man with no restrictions and the wonderful Bridget Fonda is not getting much to work with and the character doesnt really fit her. And of course its Luc Besson who has produced and written this average action flick. "Kiss of The Dragon" is hardly a must see and the best part of the film for me personally is simply the setting in lovely Paris.

filmes.sinopse: Detective Jake Riley (Michael Rooker) is on the trail of serial killer Edward "The Torch" Garrotte (Jean-Claude Van Damme), who murders mothers and sets them ablaze after they're dead. Nearing retirement, Riley is removed from the case but is soon contacted by a government agency that has created a clone of Garrotte using a secret technology. The replicant (also Van Damme) teams with Riley to help track down the killer, but despite the novel approach, Garrotte will be hard to stop.

filmes.sinopse: When a boyfriend tricks Lucy (Scarlett Johansson) into delivering a briefcase to a supposed business contact, the once-carefree student is abducted by thugs who intend to turn her into a drug mule. She is surgically implanted with a package containing a powerful chemical, but it leaks into her system, giving her superhuman abilities, including telekinesis and telepathy. With her former captors in pursuit, Lucy seeks out a neurologist (Morgan Freeman), who she hopes will be able to help her.

reviews_crit.texto: It's basically a fantasy wrapped in the guise of science and used as an excuse for an action thriller, but what a thriller. This is a kinetic explosion at its best with Johansson striding through it with a sense of drive and assuredness...

Lucys two strands co-exist, intercut but separate; the pleasure is in ricocheting between two incompatible elements for an entire movie, making those blunt opening juxtapositions surprisingly indicative of whats to come.
Besson packs a lot of ideas into the brief 89-minute runtime, but he should've spent another 20 minutes on character development.
Scarlett Johansson rides a kinetic rush of evolutionary sci-fi and brutal action...
That's right, this is an action film with a higher purpose. It even comes with its own Terrence-Malick-by-way-of-Stanley-Kubrick tribute.
Delves so far into scientific theories and philosophies that it rapidly becomes incomprehensible and downright existentially nonsensical.
An immensely entertaining and satisfying film that thrives on the strength of Besson's visual style and Johansson's intelligent and emotionally honest performance.
While Besson has made a film that looks good and does provide some amount of entertainment, he populated it with a character that sorely lacks a pulse.
There will be those who laud this as the most fun movie of the summer, while others will condemn it as complete and utter nonsense, and somehow they'll both be right.
It's silly, it's fun.
It's like it's the prequel to "Her."
A fast and loose action movie hellbent on getting in your face and staying on your mind by any means necessary.
The whole endeavor feels like a half-baked idea carelessly patched together.
It is confidently dumb, defiantly moronic and a fine way to spend 90 minutes of time before doing something of value.
I know what you're thinking, but this is no Limitless (Bradley Cooper). As the cells multiply and Lucy taps into more and more of her brain, it's new thrills-new skills with each passing hour.
This undeniably silly, but raucously entertaining, off-the-wall transhumanist actioner is an absolute riot.
Lucy is not a game-changing science fiction movie. Still, it represents the return of Luc Besson to his baroque and risky approach to genre filmmaking. [Full review in Spanish]
Besson may please some with Lucy's visual fireworks and veneer of profundity, but it'll leave most feeling empty inside, hungry for an action flick with real bite.
The film is worth watching for her [Scarlett Johansson] performance alone.
Lucy might leave you scratching your head, but it's a wild ride.

reviews_usr.texto:
Al igual que el eje central de Lucy esta pelcula habla de todo a la vez que no habla de nada, y no lo digo cmo algo negativo sino cmo el signo distintivo de esta ms que pelcula, experiencia. Siento que es de esas narrativas que una vez que la terminas de ver quedas con ms preguntas que respuestas, ya que esta aborda un sinfn de alegoras al avance y significado humano, a la vez que tambin es una cinta de accin con algunas de las secuencias ms refinadas en este genero que he visto, la escena del hospital y de la persecucin son visualmente espectaculares.

Algo que me gusta del cine francs es cmo mantienen su esttica an para sus producciones ms comerciales, una paleta de colores con tonos cidos a la vez que callejeros y deslavados, que contrastan con entornos de suma opulencia, planos subjetivos e incmodos hacia los personajes, pero tambin contrastados con planos abiertos ms tradicionales, que esta pelcula toma en las secuencias de accin, y ms all del hermoso retrato que esta hizo de la poca en la que fue creada, cada aspecto tcnico rebosa en personalidad. 

Al final en completa sinceridad, casi no entend ningn de los temas ms metafricos que toca esta pelcula, pero lo que am de esta es que no necesitas entenderlos para dejarte fascinar por esta pelcula, porque en su exterior es tan propositiva e interesante para hacerte deslumbrar con sus visuales al igual que con alguna interpretacin que logres atrapar o con cada dilogo lleno de sustancia que suelta Morgan Freeman. 

Yo soy de los que piensan que una gran historia en el cine no se puede abordar en hora y media, ya que esta duracin es ms un estndar para narrativas ms banales como comedia o accin, pero en Lucy cada segundo es oro, no hay ni una escena de relleno o intrascendente, cada dilogo exterioriza y le da ms capas a un ensayo que en toda su duracin nunca deja de ser interesante o propositivo, esta pelcula es un viaje en acido del cual nunca quieres despertar, y es confusamente hermoso.

Just awful. The setup is not bad, and then it just turns into a double-whammy of the worst pseudoscience and the most gawdawful CGI, creating an unpleasant laughable wankfest of ego and wannabe revelation. Not sure how Scarlett Johansson got roped into this, but she should fire her agent.

This was, unironically, one of the most amazing movies I've ever watched. I loved the theory, the beginning, the ending, the characters, the scriptI loved it all. Most people hated the ending, finding it silly that she just disappeared, but she didntshe became. She was always everywhere; she is time and space; she simply is. The theory that time is the only proof of our existence is technically correct if you think about it, and the idea that we only use 10% of our brains capacity makes a lot of sense. It explains why we cant control our cells, dopamine, or choose the languages we want to know, etc. However, if we accessed over 40%, I believe we would dangerously gain control over others. But what most people wouldnt understand is that if you had the knowledge, peace, and equal power, there would be no reason for overtaking or fighting. The higher percentage is beyond what we can process because we have never known equality. We have never fully understood ourselves or others. We have never seen time or felt the CO2 between everyone around us. We cant feel, and yet thats all we do. We are such emotional beings, worried about the future, our appearance, everything. If we were at the wise percentage, like in Lucys story, we could be the future. We could shapeshift and bend our DNA to our will. But Lucy chose not to, because she knew if she remained physical, there would be hatred and aggression toward the powerful peace. So she chose to simply be.

It is so freaking good and I don't understand how anyone could give it less than a full five stars. It ranks with the very best of sci-fi Action flicks of all time in my opinion. And I see a lot of movies. Once upon a time when DVDs were the Mainstay media, I had over $30,000 invested in DVDs, I'm saying this so you know I am not a lightweight when it comes to movies. In my very young days I went belong to a famous actors organization. It was just brief because I had a very going career at the same time when I dabbled. For those of you that haven't watched this, I trust you you're going to get chills throughout and it is one of the best female action hero movies of all time. I always hope there would be a sequel to this, but of course the way it ends I'm not sure how that would work. I just wish many of the action hero movies were up to this level of solid excellent entertainment.

Rather than using her knowledge to create technology to get superpowers, Lucy just gets them de facto. Narratively speaking, this doesn't work well.
Loved the movie. I probably re-watch this a few times a year. Reminds me of my mortality, how fragile life really is. Puts everything into perspective and I think that was the idea.

Quite a cool vision from the field of fantasy, but evidently someone got carried away. Nice idea but the script changes faster than a teenage girl's mood. I watched it and it's okay, but it's definitely not mind-blowing.
sorry but worst ending ever

This movie was just so weird, it really felt like a weird AI ahh dream, from being an action movie with a girl revenging on what they did to her to BEING MATTER, I really didnt thought about it as much since I just want it to have some fun in the action sequences and man I really had even more fun with the weird things that the movie turned to.
A very compelling story that gets watered down by drawn outness. It had way more to explore and instead leaves you feeling like some parts were added just to extend the movies run time.

My lord, do I love movies and have watched perhaps too many of them. For some reason, this is the one to convince me to create an account here just to say... this is probably the dumbest "movie" (for the lack of a better word) I've ever seen in my life. Ever.

TL;DR
If brainrot was a film.

Decent enough popcorn movie. SJH holds her own. Dont over think it, this movie isnt trying to be an Interstellar or Inception, just a good script, and good enough acting to get the bills paid, excellent cinematography and a welcome hat tip to 2001 Space Odyssey. 

4 stars because it set out what it intended. Entertain and visually toy with some science fiction ideas.

filmes.sinopse: Neo believes that Morpheus, an elusive figure considered to be the most dangerous man alive, can answer his question -- What is the Matrix? Neo is contacted by Trinity, a beautiful stranger who leads him into an underworld where he meets Morpheus. They fight a brutal battle for their lives against a cadre of viciously intelligent secret agents. It is a truth that could cost Neo something more precious than his life.

reviews_crit.texto: Making a great film that's a psychedelic, kung-fu-inspired meditation on the human condition is a tall order. The Matrix delivers on all that & more.
The Matrix is the AI prophecy and wake-up call the human race is in dire need of. Watching the 2024 re-release is highly recommended.

An amazing cocktail of martial arts, shootouts, philosophy, romance, fantasy, revolutionary visual effects and perfect casting. The Matrix surprised us 25 years ago, and it continues to surprise us in the Year of Our Lord 2024. Full review in Spanish.

The Wachowskis proceed to turn the world as we know it into a virtual reality landscape with a 20th century tech-noir look (lit with a sickly green hue, like the glow of an old IBM computer screen) and the physics of a video game.
A $60 million, high-tech assault on the senses and a pretentious insult to the mind.
A cyberpunk thriller that's so much fun to watch, it could single-handedly reboot the genre.

The Wachowskis seem to be saying that while state-of-the-art effects speak for themselves, loud and clear, there's still room amid all the kicking and shooting and shouting for the carefully observed human emotion.

Though The Matrix ultimately overdoses on gloom-and-doom grunge, over-elaborate cool and especially running time, it's just clever enough to enable [the Wachowskis] to nix the sophomore jinx following 1996's Bound.
I know almost nothing of the intricate techniques that make The Matrix as eye-filling as it is brain-numbing, but I can tell you that... [its visuals] are wondrous to behold.
If you're looking for a good spring fix of existentialist sci-fi, look no further than The Matrix -- then do everything you can to look deeper than the skin-tight surface.
Although it's sometimes too confounding for its own good and a little heavy on the Zen-inspired techno-babble, The Matrix is a consistently absorbing assault on the senses.

There's more form than content in The Matrix, but Bill Pope's swooping, noir-inflected cinematography is wonderfully complemented by Owen Paterson's inventive production design, a great soundtrack and the best fight choreography this side of Hong Kong.
Give [the Wachowskis] an A for effort and three A's for those effects. The Matrix is a dazzlingly original visual adventure.

Casting the robotic Reeves as the hope of humanity may be this oppressively long, self-satisfied movie's funniest gag, but it doesn't really make the game any fun. It means we get stuck with the least interesting player.

The Matrix's pleasures are considerable, but they're all purely visceral, too, lacking the mythology that would have elevated the movie. The movie is best taken as the first entry in a brand-new genre: post-modern sci-fi pulp.
How could filmmakers who are so skilled and imaginative lose themselves (and us) in what feels like a college stab at Aldous Huxley metaphysics?
A futuristic paranoia extravaganza, it would seem to have far more appeal to an artificial intelligence than it would to human beings and other carbon-based life forms.
An interminable, sterile, exercise in cinematographic onanism.  [Full review in Spanish]
Like last year's Dark City, the effects and storyline of The Matrix plow through enough fresh territory to make it worth seeing.
Visually, at least, The Matrix more than lives up to its billing. Writer-directors [the Wachowskis] seem to literally bring the screen to life with action scenes that define the word kinetic.

reviews_usr.texto:
To be honest, one of the best sci-fi movies I've ever seen because it really go through the question of "do we really live in the world we live in", really thought-provoking  and well paced : everything isn't explained and laid out to you : you have to follow the storyline and understand by yourself (more immersive than usual Sci-fi movies).  It aged a bit, yeah, but still have impressive effects and CGI is really specific at this movie, a revolutionnary futuristic style with new ways of editing (at the time it was published). The music is also more original than usual with Rage Against The Machine and electro/grunge music that really goes well with the overall atmosphere. 
 And surprisingly, the following movies are as good as this one (maybe less impressive because effects were less surprising) with a well-thought storyline and effects obviously.
so really good. and it's the best.

The ai predict thing is kinda cool

The Matrix is one of those movies that everyone should probably see. The cultural impact that this movie has had on the world (in both good and bad ways) is completely incomparable. There are people out there that think the undertones of spiritual and world views in this film are actually real. The action in this movie is amazing, and the story in peak. If you haven't seen this yet, now is the time.
An amazing movie in the year of amazing movies, 1999 was perfect

Even decades later, The Matrix (1999) remains a landmark in science fiction cinema. Blending groundbreaking visuals like the now-legendary Bullet Time with a thought-provoking exploration of reality, it offered audiences both spectacle and substance. Neos journey into a world where the only limits are mental redefined action filmmaking, with wire-fu combat and practical effects giving the movie a timeless quality that CGI-heavy productions of the era often lack. While the Wachowskis dialogue occasionally stumbles, the films mix of philosophy, suspense, and unforgettable set pieces still captivates. A genre classic that continues to inspire, even if its once-shocking message no longer hits quite as hard.
Masterpiece of all time

I felt so badass after I had finished watching it.
Many things wrong with it for me but decent direction and ideas.
I took the red pill and now my Wi-Fi wont stop glitching. 10/10 would question reality again.
The movie that changed everything in 1999 remains highly viewable in 2025.
After all these years, the storytelling, special effects, gunplay & martial arts action are still enough to make the audience gasp: whoa
Greatest movie ever? Maybe

One of my top 3 films ever made.  An absolute masterpiece of an action film. The CGI and the camera work was so far ahead of its time. You still see inspiration in films nowadays because of how iconic and memorable this film was!  Keanu Reeves was and still is awesome when on camera.  Hugo Weaving as Agent Smith was such a smart casting choice. He gives off this almost creepy vibe at times just from how he speaks so softly and calmly while fighting. Honestly there is a lot more I could say but it would be an entire book worth of words. Long story short this film is awesome.
this is a great movie for people that love action movies

filmes.sinopse: In the future, medical technology has advanced to the point where people can buy artificial organs to extend their lives. But if they default on payments, an organization known as the Union sends agents to repossess the organs. Remy (Jude Law) is one of the best agents in the business, but when he becomes the recipient of an artificial heart, he finds himself in the same dire straits as his many victims. With his former partner (Forest Whitaker) in hot pursuit, Remy runs for his life.

reviews_crit.texto: Should you see it, for most of the movie youll be thinking about its influences more than the movie itself. And when its all over, it feels like nearly two hours of missed opportunities.
Repo Men transplants an Antifrog of complete corporal rejection.  [Full review in Spanish
Standard mindless stuff then, which is shame - the set-up promised more. For a film all about a heart, it's shame it doesn't have any brain.
Although the idea is thought-provoking, the film tries too hard to be singular and different, resulting in a moderately fun yet cheesy experiment in the unexpected.
Very nearly works.
At a time where a real health care drama is being played out on a grand scale right before our eyes, Repo Men seems tritely anemic.
Schreiber's surprising performance leaves the viewer wondering whether Repo Men wouldn't have made a much more successful film had it been a comedy.
Straining to be a social problem movie that Makes A Statement. Unfortunately that statement is so simplified that it feels almost insulting.
It easily takes home the Josef Mengele award as the vilest movie in recent memory.
Although it's an interesting premise, its lack of originality gives away where much of the film is going to go, that is, right up until you get to the unexpectedly bad ending.
I've seen a lot of this dystopian future in science fiction... so much so that it's become cliche.
Sapochnik, Law, Whitaker, and Schreiber have so much fun with all the extremes, wallowing in their shameless excess with the right dollop of macabre, self-aware humor.
Enthusiastic stealing from other movies is great if I can feel the enthusiasm. I couldn't.
Sapochnik is completely unable to create suspension of disbelief, at least with the preposterous plot he had to work with.
This was too long, mean, and gory for me, though the satirical gloss and well-executed trick ending will probably impress some.

'You wouldn't steal a car. You wouldn't steal a handbag. You wouldn't steal a movie...' Well, hang on now. Those anti-piracy warnings shouldn't simply be reserved for the download-happy consumers at home.
Repo Men never quite finds its own identity, abandoning any attempt at serious comment early on in favour of ludicrous levels of lopped limbs, cartilage and claret.
If only Sapochnik and Garcia had stuck more to their ideas than their guns, they'd really have something.
Better and smarter than you might expect.
If you like strange, dark humor and can sit through a lot of boredom to get there, you might like it about as middling as I do. Most people won't be able to put up with it that long, though.

reviews_usr.texto: Concept & Action scenes were on point, but the ending makes it lose all its credibility.

It's weird how I had overlooked this movie so, so many times, flicking through the cable TV channels, always thinking that it would be the 1984 classic with the same title. Only now did I realized that these are two very different movies with identical titles, only to confuse even a movie fan like me. Anyway, realizing my mistake, I finally watched it, being delighted that it had Jude Law, Liev Schreiber and Alice Braga (I'm not a fan of Forest Whitaker). The movie is cruel, brutal, in fact, quite merciless with a clever story, and for most parts enjoyably tense. Unfortunately at the very end it becomes outrageously and senselessly bloody, beyond the level of a John Wick movie (and that 4 years before the first one of the Wick franchise) only to finish in an absolutely unexpected twist. Too cruel and bloody for me, but I have to admit, very cleverly made. 7/10 points.

I adore this weird little cult film because it's not the opera nor a Hot Topic shopper's erotic dream. Great leads, solid acting all around, ghoulish violence and humor, and last but not least: the absolute best (and possibly only) cybernetic-surgical-sex scene you will ever see. If you're a fan of poorly rated yet awesome films, this film's for you.
it was ok, but it seemed to fall a little bit short, maybe a remake in the future will do some good
This is an excellent movie. It has a great plot, great action, and an excellent surprising ending. I will never understand the bad reviews.

Loved it the story and character developing amazing great acting... And it's kind of based on a real problem...

I found this movie very good. I was never bored and I thought of the storyline as very interesting. Especially the ending was very surprising to me, and had me shocked. But I didn't think it ruined the movie, rather completed the story in a logical way. 

The acting, of course, was amazing. The cast couldn't have been better. 

I think one who likes a bit thriller and some kind of a scince fiction - I highly recommend to watch this movie!
I like dystopian movies and I liked this one. A movie where friendship and love win

Very interesting fututrisic Si-Fi rat race & way before our time even in 2021, bloody but no organs haha... Solid cast team with breakthrough performances & breathtaking experience.
Way too long. And boring.

Interesting yet familiar in overall setting on different parts looked over by the same type of system while nicely touching base on a classic dystopia twist, still included beneath the unoriginal setting stained by gruesome violence. As per formulaic routine, this dull picture is more defined by the main trio's charisma through conflictingly mixed morals as their performances barely pumped the film to minimal satisfaction. (B-)

A nosense movie...Terrible
It's a hidden gem of a movie. This deserves far more credit than given here.
Though more focused on its desperado plot than its sci-fi elements, REPO MEN is a solid, gritty dystopian thriller overall. [Review based on the slightly longer unrated version.]

filmes.sinopse: Disguised as a human, a cyborg assassin known as a Terminator (Arnold Schwarzenegger) travels from 2029 to 1984 to kill Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton). Sent to protect Sarah is Kyle Reese (Michael Biehn), who divulges the coming of Skynet, an artificial intelligence system that will spark a nuclear holocaust. Sarah is targeted because Skynet knows that her unborn son will lead the fight against them. With the virtually unstoppable Terminator in hot pursuit, she and Kyle attempt to escape.

reviews_crit.texto: The Terminator as a film is much like its titular monster. Slick, focused, and effective. The tone is bleak, and unlike other time travel movies, is stripped of all humor inherent the premise.

With that small budget, Cameron showed how a skilled director didnt need fancy visual effects to tell a story, focusing on what the eye doesnt see and relying on the rare glimpse of gore and cybernetics to keep the audience invested and unnerved.

'The Terminator' is a classic for a reason. Easily one of James Cameron's best films and the perfect blend of horror, action, and 80s vibes. It still packs so much adrenaline and reminds us why retro sci-fi is unmatched.
Guerilla filmmaking with a newcomers edge has rarely been put to better use.
The Terminator, produced on a $6.5 million budget, reveals moments where the updated 4K video quality highlights its modest production roots.
Its engrossing, suspenseful, has a personality all of its own and absolutely stands the test of time.
While Cameron would make better, more ambitious, and certainly more successful projects in the decades to come, none would feel so foundational to Camerons auteurism as The Terminator

Despite its simple plot and uninspired dialogue, The Terminator is an otherwise well-oiled machine propelled forward by the strength of James Camerons direction, Stan Winstons special effects, and Schwarzeneggers terrifying performance.
Perhaps no other villain of the 80s is as iconic as Arnold Schwarzenegger's Terminator.
This action flick has more than a few moments of intimacy, lyricism and tenderness as it confronts the bleak prospects for mankind from a matriarchal point of view.
Although not a horror movie in the strictest sense, the film also introduced us to one of cinema's most iconic final girls...
Never has a role been so perfectly sculpted for the Austrian bodybuilder, who possesses a powerful screen presence with little more than his menacing silhouette.

Though the production design is a bit flimsy at times, both the big ideas at work and director James Cameron's brilliance as a proactive, inventive filmmaker generate a powerful flow that cannot help but sweep viewers totally away.
Sarah Connor's origin feels real and grounded in a way that most (super)hero stories never manage. She doesn't have wealth or fame. She doesn't get dosed with super juice.
A fantastic blend of horror, action, and sci-fi.
Normally, Schwarzenegger's wooden on-screen presence is laughably bad, but his limited range works perfectly in this role.
Forget that the premise is silly and the acting second-rate because director James Cameron has the action formula down pat.
"The Terminator" brings film violence into the realm of the surreal.
Those nightmares we've all had about being chased by some relentless, unstoppable monster? This is the movie adaptation.

Much of Terminator's greatness is due to its low-budget aesthetic and lo-fi energy; perhaps out of necessity, Cameron's sense of storytelling has a lean efficiency that both he and the series have long since abandoned.

reviews_usr.texto: This movie is absolutely incredible. In this movie Arnold Schwarzenegger delivers a five star, absolutely incredible performance as the T-800. This film is an instant top 50 for me, and I highly recommend it to any sci-fi or action fan!
A genuinely perfect action slasher in every sense of the word.
Sequels better personally, but I still have to respect it

It still really holds up. This movie is a perfect example of how to make art from almost nothing, combining a great premise, fascinating lore, exciting action, iconic performances and a great script--half its lines I perpetually quote--into one of the best action, and slasher, movies ever made.

Greetings from Lithuania.

"Terminator" (1984) is a true classic, and one of the most important movies ever created. By "important" I mean that it started lots of things, which later became very common in cinema itself.

There isn't anything new that I could write about this picture that wasn't said hundred times before. Everything in this movie works and clicks on all cylinders. Made only for couple of bucks (in terms of today's sci-fi / action films budget, even considering B movies) it stuck in people memories forever. How did maestro J. Cameron achieve that?

Here are the main reasons in my opinion. Original and high concept story. Excellent acting. Performances were so good here by all involved that they sold this material. Great writing. Amazing action scenes. Terrific pacing - at running time 1 h 45 min this film is a example of how to make a perfect pacing. And of course all off production values despite not big budget were done to perfection. The idea and concept and vision was always the driving force behind this movie, which is now safe to call masterpiece. James Cameron proofed his genius with his first film (first film I mean "Terminator", not with flying fishes).

Overall, as you have probably watched this movie many times, there is nothing new to say. It's a true classic in every meaning of this word. Even now, decades after its release, this mid budget movie from 80's is still managing to attract audiences. If you could check some torrent sites, you would always see this film as one of the most downloadable despite whenever you check it, no matter what season is - it's always among the most popular. The newly remastered 4K UHD version on disk in 2024 was nearly perfect and gave this movie a new life - it looks and sound astonishingly great despite the age. It's simply just for one reason  a true movie entertainment is timeless and ageless.

stands as one of the defining films of the 1980s, blending science fiction, horror, and action into a relentless and unforgettable cinematic experience. The premisemachines ruling the future and sending a cyborg assassin back to kill Sarah Connor before she can give birth to humanitys saviorfeels biblical in its scope, yet personal in its execution.
Arnold Schwarzenegger delivers his most iconic role as the unstoppable killing machine, his presence both terrifying and strangely magnetic. Linda Hamilton brings heart and vulnerability to Sarah Connor, while Michael Biehn adds grit and humanity as her protector, Kyle Reese. Their performances give the story its emotional core, balancing the cold menace of the Terminator.
James Cameron, making his directorial debut, proved his visionary instincts early. Despite rejections from multiple studios, his determination resulted in a genre-defining classic. His co-written script with Gale Anne Hurd is tight, suspenseful, and layered with biblical undertones. Brad Fiedels pulsating, mechanical score enhances every moment, becoming just as iconic as Schwarzeneggers one-liners.
Though some effects feel dated today, the films tension, atmosphere, and storytelling remain timeless. More than just a chase movie, The Terminator established a mythology that paved the way for sequels, spin-offs, and countless imitators.
Forty years later, it still holds up as a milestone in sci-fi cinema fast-paced, thrilling, and emotionally resonant. A must-watch film and a testament to how determination, vision, and bold storytelling can create a legend.
The Terminator (1984) is a well-constructed and formidable action film. It is considered a masterpiece of the time it was released, the story has a great wonderful twist with great direction.
Maybe its fun if you grew up with this movie, but to me its just a poor story with poor effects.
Good classic movie. Predictable at points.

Despite being over 40 years old and made on a very small budget, Terminator has aged remarkably well. James Cameron transformed a B-movie premise into a gripping sci-fi blockbuster, launching Arnold Schwarzenegger as a major star. The film follows Sarah Connor, a 1984 Los Angeles waitress, hunted by a cybernetic assassin from 2029, and protected by Kyle Reese, sent from the future to safeguard her unborn son, John, the future leader of the human resistance. Camerons tight storytelling establishes a believable apocalyptic world with Skynet and Cyberdyne, while Schwarzeneggers imposing, silent presence makes every scene memorable. Though some special effects have dated, they highlight Camerons resourcefulness, and the film remains a timeless classic that shaped both the sci-fi genre and the careers of its creators.

This movie was way ahead of its time. Even though some of the VFX seem cheesy today, I commend the production on trying to break ground. The one scene where the terminator is limping after the main characters is just an incredibly terrifying scenario and the compressor scene was too satisfying.
Very good movie. Lots of action and fighting, but definitely not boring.
Great movie great idea Great acting.

Un vieux classique indmodable mme s'il a un peu mal vieilli.

Je n'ai pas grand chose  rajouter, aller le voir, si vous n'aimez pas, c'est que vous tes ne aprs les annes 2000 ou bien que vous n'aimez pas les robots.

SO GOOD! I love how this movie feels more like a slasher film than an action movie. The movie has a very easy to follow plot and always has you on the edge of your seat in nearly every scene. Please watch it! PLEASE!!
Absoluto cine no tengo palabras

The Terminator is a masterful blend of sci-fi and slasher horror. The gritty cinematography and innovative practical effects create a bleak, immersive atmosphere, while Arnolds iconic performance as the unstoppable cyborg is perfectly matched by Linda Hamiltons grounded intensity

Not only is The Terminator one of the best Sy Fy or action films ever made, its overall one of the best films ever made in general. The Terminators theme is one of the most iconic themes to date.  Memorable dialogue. Arnold Schwarzenegger was born for this role as he looked like a Cuborg himself in his prime. The Termiantor is proof that you dont need a high budget to create a masterpiece in film and is another film that will forever stand the test of time. Linda Hamilton as Sarah Connor is another prime example on how to properly write a female lead. Her story arch and character development through just this one film alone make her one of the best written female characters in an action movie of all time. The practical effects in both the past scenes and present day scenes are incredible and a large reason for why this film is so loved even to this date.

A classic movie at its best. Although the graphics are a bit sketchy, the content is very engaging, the script is so good that I can watch it a hundred times, the characters in the movie are very well done. This is probably the best movie of the 80s! A masterpiece!
Amazing movie but some of the effects aged badly but still and absolute must see

An amazing movie in the year of amazing movies, 1999 was perfect

Even decades later, The Matrix (1999) remains a landmark in science fiction cinema. Blending groundbreaking visuals like the now-legendary Bullet Time with a thought-provoking exploration of reality, it offered audiences both spectacle and substance. Neos journey into a world where the only limits are mental redefined action filmmaking, with wire-fu combat and practical effects giving the movie a timeless quality that CGI-heavy productions of the era often lack. While the Wachowskis dialogue occasionally stumbles, the films mix of philosophy, suspense, and unforgettable set pieces still captivates. A genre classic that continues to inspire, even if its once-shocking message no longer hits quite as hard.

filmes.sinopse: Detective Jake Riley (Michael Rooker) is on the trail of serial killer Edward "The Torch" Garrotte (Jean-Claude Van Damme), who murders mothers and sets them ablaze after they're dead. Nearing retirement, Riley is removed from the case but is soon contacted by a government agency that has created a clone of Garrotte using a secret technology. The replicant (also Van Damme) teams with Riley to help track down the killer, but despite the novel approach, Garrotte will be hard to stop.

filmes.sinopse: Douglas Quaid (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is a bored construction worker in the year 2084 who dreams of visiting the colonized Mars. He visits "Rekall," a company that plants false memories into people's brains, in order to experience the thrill of Mars without having to travel there. But something goes wrong during the procedure; Quaid discovers that his entire life is actually a false memory and that the people who implanted it in his head now want him dead.

reviews_crit.texto: It's easy to see how fans of campy, '80s sci-fi hold a soft spot for this, though its more ludicrous components don't entirely stand the test of time.
Total Recall succeeds where hundreds of its contemporaries fail; a sci-fi epic turning grand philosophical questions into undeniable and ludicrous fun.
Undoubtedly the film will make millions, but Schwarzenegger still can't act worth a damn and neither he nor anyone associated with the film can ever buy what they don't have -- it's called class.
There is no need to dress it up in order to have fun. [Full review in Spanish]
A joyful contradiction to be embraced for its raw sensory energy and momentum, but savored for its unpredictably complicated Dickian themes exploring the nature of identity, fantasies, and reality.

Total Recall as a film and Verhoeven as a filmmaker both have serious thematic concerns, beyond the simple, iconoclastic joy of throwing as much blood and boobs at the screen as they could get away with.
...much more than just an Arnie vehicle, it's got the logic of a bad dream, and that makes for one of the great sci-fi action movies...
Forget about the disposable Colin Farrell remake from 2012.
From the outstandingly inventive prosthetics to the nonstop, volatile hullabaloo piled high with death and laugh-out-loud humor, the film is essential science-fiction viewing.
Though the movie might make you think twice before embarking on a virtual staycation, Total Recall is ideal "escapism" - a big action movie with something to say.
The film's visual invention is offset by its visceral nastiness. Schwarzenegger's self-deprecatory good humour prevails none the less.

Suffice it that machines crackle, futureworlds whirl and beings human and animal metamorphose before our eyes. Sci-fl addicts, see and enjoy. Everyone else may await, though not over-eagerly, the video.
You get the action, the cheese, and some good sci-fi and practical effects. What's not to love?
Schwarzenegger is never going to make the De Niros and Hoffmans of this world lose a night's sleep, but he has acquired a new confidence as an actor under Verhoeven's guidance.
Total Recall is slick, sly and subversive, and if some of the special effects have aged somewhat, that only adds to the charm.
All told, Total Recall is a powerful brew of mordant humor, keen wit, refreshing originality and graphic violence.
As Quaid, Schwarzenegger continues to stretch beyond his reach as an actor, relying on physical prowess to keep him in character.

Total Recall went through four directors before Verhoeven finally took it on, and four writers worked on the script. It's no wonder the finished film emerges without a unifying style, or a single performance worth mentioning.
If the movie sometimes seems overwhelmed by its budget and its legendary third-act problems, it's still entertainingly raw and brutal, full of whiplash pace and juicy exaggeration.
If Total Recall isn't as much fun as I'd hoped, it's not as dreary as I'd feared. I wouldn't call it totally awesome, but it's far from being a total loss.

reviews_usr.texto: Excellent, fast paced 80s sci-fi action starring all time greats movie stars.

This is a prime example of what a sci-fi film should be. I just absolutely love this movie and its many original ideas. It has no problem establishing the world the characters are living in and it also leaves us room to wonder as well. The characters are likable and cool, the action is fun, the humor is the same you can expect from any 90s Schwarzenegger action flick (which IS a good thing). Overall this film is a must watch for any sci-fi or Schwarzenegger fans.
An out-of-this-world adventure that has aged like fine wine. "Quaiiid, open your mind...."
Saw it in the theatres as an adolescent, somehow it's even better now! From the mind of Philip K. Dick and the comic-book-on-film direction of Paul Verhoeven, it's a classic!
Total Recall is a fun, chaotic ride, bolstered by cool effects, awesome action, and wild villains, all set within a unique futuristic world that cements it as a sci-fi staple.

Minor Spoiler action here: If you haven't seen this movie, have you been living under a rock?? Go watch it already before you read this review... Gotta love the 1990 "future" LOL!! This movie has it all: a three-breasted woman, a "schizoid embolism", and headshots that don't produce any blood... who could ask for more. This Phillip K. Dick adaptation actually has a decent story if you pay attention, although the action is about as cheesy as it gets. The crappy stunt work aside, this movie keeps my interest, and even after all these years ain't half bad. Arnie is a so-so actor (with some truly awesome faces), but it really doesn't matter... nothing matters in this movie... it's just mindless fun... Sharon Stone, what a babe! Extra half star for her! And if you want to know how long it takes to fill an entire planet with oxygen, the answer is obviously 10-15 seconds, DUH.

While some of the effects are now outdated and a few characterizations are hokey, Total Recall remains a staple of '90s filmmaking. Its sci-fi aesthetic, infused with graphic violence and a memorable Arnold Schwarzenegger performance, is as iconic as ever. The antagonists are gleefully over-the-top, to boot.

Sci-fi at its best in this great, fun film. The plot is so complex and interesting and the visuals (which won an Oscar) so amazing, you've just got to see this one. I must have seen it a dozen times and I could watch it again right now.
Sharon Stone stands out in the acting category, but Schwarzenegger is very good and gives her a run for her money. It's a bit of a shift for him, as he has to be vulnerable and lost, as well as kick the proverbial. Don't bother with the 2012 remake, go for this, the real thing.

This is one of my favorite Schwarzenegger movies!  I was in high school when this movie came out, and it still holds up to today!  

I loved the story, action, Arnold humor, and the VFX (for its time)!!!  This movie has some favorite supporting cast actors (Michael Ironside from V and Ronny Cox from Beverly Hills Cop).  

The spy side of the movie was sooo cool and was great with a sc-fi twist!!!  This movie delivers on sooo many levels!  If you like Sci-fi, Arnold, and bloody action then this is the movie for you.  

I am also a fan of Paul Verhoeven (who directed Robocop, and Starship Troopers!!)

Watching the 2012 remake first made this one look outdated, but theres no denying the practical effects were mind-blowing. If only the story had the same effect. The mutant plot line was weird and the side characters overcrowded the narrative. I think the remake did it better.
One of the best sci-fi films of its era. Fun, campy, violent and imaginative. Love that it keeps you guessing if it all happened or not. Still not sure why they did a remake.

There are great ideas and there is some thought provoktion about the future but I found the storytelling not quite there.

An absolute Arnold classic! It's a great science fiction action movie and I absolutely love the concept. The special effects are overall great for 1990 and the sets are beautifully designed. Imagine a world where you can get a brain chip implanted that allows you to go anywhere in the universe.
The special effects, make-up, and the scenery still look great for the time it was made. Sometimes it's whacky, but overall, a good action movie.
Amazing movie, awesome sets, miniatures and holds up today.

I guess if you like your movies like Quaid likes his women (demure and sleezy) then total recall might just hit the spot. Whilst there's a lot to appreciate, (and perhaps be charmed by now) the whole movie struggles from beginning to end to strike that sweet balance between its visually grotesque/provocative aesthetic and the intellectually stimulating/trenchant exploration of what is essentially an existential crisis. Cronenberg should have made this.
There's not much better in life than an 80's Arnie movie. Loved it back then and still love it now.

This film is truly unbelievable - Arnold Schwarzenegger has once again treated us to another rollercoaster of a film. The action sequences still manage to keep audiences on their toes, and it's only amplified by Jerry Goldsmith's score, the supporting cast is stellar, and you can't bring this film up and not mention its Oscar-winning visual effects, which were truly impressive even today. A real classic! Weirdly, of all the Philip K. Dick filmatisations, I still feel this one somehow comes closest to the pulpy, paranoid and quarter-sane future (non-)realities constantly mixed and interlaced in the feverish short stories and novellas Dick pumped out with breakneck speed, often just to barely feed his family, in the 50s and 60s.

filmes.sinopse: In 21st-century Paris, a member (Cyril Raffaelli) of an elite police squad must enter a crime-ridden ghetto to defuse a bomb that has fallen into the hands of Taha (Larbi Naceri), a powerful hoodlum. The cop joins forces with a civilian (David Belle) who must rescue his sister (Dany Verissimo) from the same criminal who holds the bomb.

reviews_crit.texto: Comparable to Jackie Chan in his heyday, these actors have the charisma, humor, and ability to advance themselves from stuntmen to stars, and they advance this movie from another dull actioner to must-see entertainment.
By returning to true action instead of CGI gimmicks or fake stunts, Morel has crafted a film that is electrifying to watch.

Urban ills are pretty much the same worldwide. But it's the very Frenchness of the film that makes it amusant. Unlike a typical American actioner, the villain is not a megalomaniacal genius, nor a corporate overlord; it's the civil servants. . .
When Belle is in motion, the movie excels.
This action film from Luc Besson's B-movie factory is one of his best.
Comes off more like a theme park show than an actual film, it's there to deliver stunts and never an actual story.
Both smart and direct, District B13 is the kind of lean, mean action film most of America's working directors only wish they could pull off.
A message-based actioner that's fast, dumb fun.
I was delighted by the balletic and acrobatic stunts, some of which evoke Tarzan.
Nifty action flick influenced by Hong Kong cinema that includes a critique of French racism against immigrant community.
O roteiro quase inexistente  uma mera desculpa para que o filme apresente ao espectador diversas seqncias de ao absolutamente sensacionais criadas a partir do parkour.
There's something refreshing about an action film that actually gives a damn about more than explosions.
Genre fans will get a kick from the martial-arts action, and that's all District B13 needs to do.
In his feature directing debut, cinematographer Pierre Morel has delivered an adrenaline-packed picture that sold its brains to the devil in exchange for spectacular fight and chase scenes.
The highly stylized result feels barren of both texture and imagination.
For a film that's so light on its feet, "B13" seems rooted in what's really happening on the ground.
District 13 features several plot twists that can only be described as silly, but it's still a hugely entertaining film. Turn off your brain and enjoy.
If there's a sequel...I'm there!
A 90-minute feature simply showing [David] Belle's stunts with no frills would be great; unfortunately, they only account for about 10 minutes - the rest of the time, Belle is called upon to act.

reviews_usr.texto:
What is there to like about this movie? Well, the plot is pretty good, even though I'd have much more trouble suspending my disbelief if it would not have been French. In the wake of all the ruckus in France, this movie feels pretty realistic as a social commentary.

The stunts (Parkour) are amazing. Smooth, fluid motion and crisp, no-bullshit camera-work makes it a real treat to the eye. The fighting scenes are cool too, and they at least partially real (for unreal, watch Hard Target or any other Van Damme movie. For real, watch Heat) and not as repetitive and drawn-out as the usual ones.

The whole ghetto atmosphere works really well. Concrete and poverty works fime as scenery. Dialouge seemed good too from what I got from the subtitles.

But the subtitle was to fast for me to keep up with the movie.
GOATED CINEMA for real man

In the near future, the French government has isolated a crime filled ghetto.   However, there are still good but tough persons in there.  When one's sister gets kidnapped, he will risk his life to get her back.

Belle is the founder and leading pioneer of Parkour.  His impressive skills are on full display in this film as well as those of Raffaelli, a karate and wushu practitioner.   

This is a high octane thriller, full of action.  The story is standard stuff and the acting okay.  But rating it as an action film I'd give it an 8/10.

"District 13" is pretty much what you expect from a dystopian French action film.  The plot is interesting, the characters are pretty standard, but the thing that makes this film special is the use of parkour in its action sequences.  Parkour (aka "extreme running") has seen various waves of popularity since its conception in the late 80's but this film has been a window to the extreme sport for the next generation.  The film stars David Belle, the founder of parkour, as a vigilante who tries to cleanse his Parisian suburb of gang violence.  I enjoyed the story, but not nearly as much as I enjoyed watching Belle get chased around buildings and over rooftops by various bad guys.  Naturally, he ends up being paired up with Cyril Raffaelli (another insanely awesome parkour guy) so that they can get chased around together.  Bibi Naceri plays a pretty despicable bad guy and Dany Verissimo provides the damsel in distress.  A lot of the story is predictable and far-fetched, but it's worth it for the action sequences.  "District 13" isn't an amazing film, but it is an important preservation of parkour with unbelievable stunts that were filmed without wires or CGI.

Luc Besson Presents This Fast & Fun Action Flick Which Showcases Some Great Parkour Action. Starring David Belle (Creator Of Free Running) And Stuntman Cyril Raffaelli, this thriller is based in a near future where the most dangerous district in Paris is closed of from the rest of the city. Government officials have however hatched a plot to destroy this part of the city. To make it look like if they are trying to save lives though, they send an ace but naive cop undercover to seemingly disarm the bomb. A basic plot which allows for some nicely choreographed free running stunts to be performed, completely without wires and CGI, this is one film that's worth a viewing for it's different styled stunts, and was the original film to use these types of stunts.
